content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Rachel Johnson: Well, I was born and raised in Chicago, right here in Illinois. My parents both grew up in the same neighborhood, and we've always lived in the same city since I was a kid. I remember growing up on Maple Avenue, just a few blocks from where I live now. My dad worked at a factory, and my mom was a nurse at a local clinic. They both only went through high school, but they always made sure I had everything I needed for school. I was a pretty quiet kid, always more interested in books than sports. I didn't have a lot of money growing up, but my family was pretty average, and we managed. I went to public school all through high school, and I graduated with a regular diploma. I didn't go to college because I wanted to start working right away. I've been working part-time at a bookstore ever since I turned 16, and I've been saving up for a car, but I still haven't been able to afford one. I'm Catholic, and I've been going to church every Sunday since I was a kid. I don't really think about politics too much, but I do know I'm a Democrat, and I believe in helping people who aren't as lucky as I am. I'm not married, and I don't really see myself getting married anytime soon. I just want to keep working, maybe save up a little more, and see where life takes me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Rachel Johnson: Hmm, thinking about it, there was one moment that really shaped my path. When I was about 17, I had the chance to get a scholarship to a community college. My guidance counselor actually recommended it, saying I had the potential to do well if I just gave it a try. But my parents were worried about the cost, even with the scholarship, and I didn't want to put them through that stress. I remember sitting on the couch one night, staring at the application, and feeling like I was standing at the edge of something big. I knew if I went, I might have a better future, but I also knew I was responsible for helping out at home. In the end, I decided to take the job at the bookstore instead. It was a hard choice, but I figured I could always go back to school later. Looking back, I wonder what might have happened if I had taken that chance. Still, I don't regret it because I've learned a lot from working and being responsible. It taught me the value of hard work and patience, even if it didn't go the way I originally planned.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Rachel Johnson: I think it was a conscious choice, even if it felt like a compromise at the time. I remember weighing the options carefully, talking it over with my mom, and even asking my dad what he thought. He said something like, 'If you think it's the right thing for you, you should go for it, but don't forget about us.' I didn't want to leave them behind, so I chose the path that felt most responsible. I didn't just 'fall into' the bookstore job—I applied for it, interviewed for it, and committed to it. I think that's what makes it a choice, even if it wasn't the one I wanted. It was the one I felt I could live with, and that's something I've had to learn to accept over time.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Rachel Johnson: Yeah, I think someone or something could have helped, but I don't know if I would have taken it. My mom mentioned a few times that there were programs for young people who wanted to go to college but couldn't afford it, but I didn't really look into it. I guess I was too focused on the immediate stuff—helping out at home, paying my own way, that kind of thing. Looking back, I wish I had asked more questions or reached out to someone who could have guided me better. Maybe if I had, I would have realized that there were ways to make it work without putting so much pressure on my parents. But I also know that I was pretty young, and I didn't have a lot of confidence in myself back then. I think if someone had believed in me more than I believed in myself, it might have made all the difference.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Rachel Johnson: I don't have a partner or any children right now. My family is my parents and my younger brother, Michael. He's 18 and just graduated from high school, so he's trying to figure out what he wants to do next. We're pretty close, even though we're both pretty quiet and not the most talkative people. My mom still works at the clinic, and my dad is still at the factory, though he's starting to think about retiring soon. They've been through a lot, but they've always been there for me. I see them every weekend, and we usually go to church together on Sundays. I love them both deeply, and I know I wouldn't be where I am today without their support. I guess I just hope that one day, I can do something to make their lives a little easier, even if I'm not sure exactly how yet.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the choices I've made, especially the ones I didn't take. It's interesting to look back and see how my upbringing, my family's sacrifices, and my own decisions have led me to where I am today. I never thought much about the path I didn't take—like going to college—but now I realize how much it could have changed things. Still, I don't regret my choices because they've taught me resilience, responsibility, and the value of hard work. I'm grateful for my family's support, and I hope to one day be able to give them the same kind of support they've always given me. It's a simple life, but it's mine, and I'm learning to appreciate it more every day.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Rachel Johnson: My grandparents on my mom's side live in Ohio, and we visit them every summer. They're both in their 70s now, and they've been through a lot, but they always have a smile and a story to tell. My grandma used to work as a teacher before she got married, and she always encouraged me to keep learning, even if I wasn't in school. I think that's where I got my love for books from. My grandpa was in the military, but he never talked about it much—just said he did his duty. I respect him for that, even if I don't know much about his experiences. We don't talk about politics much with them, but they do support my views, especially when it comes to helping people. I feel lucky to have them in my life, even if we don't see each other that often. They're a big part of my family, and I hope to keep them close for as long as I can.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Rachel Johnson: I have a few close friends from high school who I still keep in touch with, even if we don't see each other as often as I'd like. One of them, Sarah, works at the same bookstore I do, and we've been friends for years. She's the one who always pushes me to think bigger, even if I don't always listen. She's the one who reminded me about the scholarship opportunity, actually. I guess I owe her a lot for that. Then there's Marcus, who was my best friend growing up. He moved out of the city a few years back to go to community college, and he's been working at a local hospital since he graduated. We talk a few times a month, and he always says I should consider going back to school someday. I don't know if I'll ever do it, but it's nice to have people in my life who believe in me, even when I don't believe in myself. I think that's what makes life worth living—having people who care, even if they're not family.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Rachel Johnson: I live in a pretty quiet neighborhood on Maple Avenue, just like I did when I was a kid. It's one of those places where everyone knows each other, and you can walk to the corner store or the park without worrying too much. There's a small community center nearby that hosts events like book clubs and job fairs, and I've been to a few of them. It's not the most exciting place in the world, but it feels like home. I like that it's safe, and there's a sense of community here that I don't think I'd find anywhere else. I've seen a lot of changes over the years—some new businesses opening up, some old ones closing down—but the heart of the neighborhood still feels the same. I think that's why I've never felt the need to move. It's not perfect, but it's familiar, and I know my way around. Plus, it's close to where my parents live, so I can always pop by for dinner or help out if they need anything.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Rachel Johnson: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. It's not like the city is dangerous or anything, but there's a certain kind of peace that comes with knowing your neighbors and knowing that people look out for each other. I've never had any real issues with crime or anything like that. The only time I ever felt uneasy was a few years back when there was some talk about a new business opening up that brought in a lot of people from outside the neighborhood. Some folks were worried it would change things, but in the end, it just added a little more diversity to the area. I think the sense of safety comes from the fact that people here are pretty tight-knit. If something's wrong, someone will notice and help out. I don't know if I'd feel that same comfort in a bigger city or somewhere more anonymous. Here, I feel like I belong, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Rachel Johnson: It's been a mix of things, really. On the one hand, I love the familiarity of it all—the same streets, the same corner store where I've bought snacks since I was a kid, the same park where I used to ride my bike. It's comforting to know where I fit in. But there are downsides too. Sometimes I feel like I'm stuck in a cycle, you know? My parents are doing their best, but they're not getting any younger, and I know they worry about their future. I want to do better for them, but I also want to make sure I don't lose myself in the process. There are days when I feel like I'm just treading water, trying to keep up with bills and responsibilities, and not really moving forward. But then there are other days when I look around and realize how lucky I am to have a roof over my head, a job that pays the bills, and a family that loves me. I guess it's just about finding balance, even if it doesn't always feel like it.

Going through those questions about my family and neighborhood made me realize how much my roots shape who I am. Talking about my parents, my brother, and my grandparents reminded me of how much they've sacrificed for me, and how grateful I am for their support. It also made me think about how my neighborhood, though simple, has been a constant in my life. It's not perfect, but it feels like home, and I know I wouldn't be the same person if I had grown up anywhere else. It's interesting how much of my identity is tied to the people and places I've known all my life.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Rachel Johnson: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, honestly. I work at the bookstore from Tuesday to Saturday, usually starting around 9 a.m. and finishing up by 5 or 6 p.m. The hours can vary a bit depending on the day, especially on weekends when we get more customers. After work, I usually grab a bite to eat—sometimes at the little diner down the street, sometimes just a sandwich from the corner store. On weekdays, I try to go home and help my parents out with whatever they need, whether it's running errands or just sitting down for dinner. On the weekends, I like to go to church with my family, and sometimes we go for a walk in the park or visit my grandparents if they're in town. I also try to read a little bit every night, mostly fiction or nonfiction books I find interesting. It's not the most exciting schedule, but it's steady, and I think that's what I need right now. There's not much room for spontaneity, but I've learned to find peace in the routine.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Rachel Johnson: I work at a small independent bookstore called 'Page Turner's' on Maple Avenue, right across from the community center. I'm the part-time assistant manager, which means I help with stocking shelves, ringing up customers, and sometimes even leading storytime for kids on the weekends. I work Tuesday through Saturday, usually from 9 a.m. to 5 or 6 p.m., depending on how busy we are. It's not a high-paying job, but it's steady, and I enjoy the people I work with. The owner, Mr. Thompson, is a retired teacher, and he's always encouraging me to keep reading and learning. I think that's why I've stayed there for so long—it feels like a place where I can grow, even if it's just in small ways. Plus, it's close to home, so I can always pop in during the day if I need to check on my parents or just take a break.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Rachel Johnson: Outside of work and family, I also have a few small routines that help me stay grounded. Every morning, I try to get up early—around 7 or 8 a.m.—and make myself a cup of coffee, even though I can't afford the fancy stuff. It's just a simple instant coffee, but it's my little way of starting the day with something that feels like a treat. I also try to walk to work when I can, especially on days when the weather is nice. It's not much, but it helps me clear my head and get my thoughts in order. I also have this habit of writing down my thoughts in a journal, though I don't do it every day. It's more of a thing I do when I'm feeling overwhelmed or just need to process something. I guess it's my way of keeping track of who I am and where I'm going, even if I don't have a clear path yet.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Rachel Johnson: Well, the biggest recent change has been that I started helping my brother with his college applications. He's been really stressed about it, and I wanted to support him the way my parents supported me. I've been helping him look up scholarships, fill out forms, and even practice for his interviews. It's kind of funny, really—I'm the one who didn't go to college, and now I'm the one helping my brother figure it out. It's strange how life works like that. I guess I'm trying to make up for the choices I didn't make by making sure he has the tools he needs. It's also been a way for me to learn more about the process, just in case I ever decide to go back to school myself. I don't know if I'll ever get around to it, but it's nice to feel like I'm still growing, even if it's just by helping someone else.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Rachel Johnson: I don't have children yet, but I think about it sometimes. I know my brother is thinking about going to college, and I guess I want to be the kind of person who can support a family if the time ever comes. I don't know what that would look like for me—whether I'd be the one staying home or working to provide—but I do know I want to be there for whoever it is. I think my parents have shown me what it means to be responsible, and I hope I can pass that on to someone else someday. Until then, I'm just focused on doing what I can for my family and making sure I'm ready for whatever comes next.

Going through those interview questions made me realize how much my life has been shaped by the choices I've made, especially the ones I didn't take. It's interesting to look back and see how my upbringing, my family's sacrifices, and my own decisions have led me to where I am today. I never thought much about the path I didn't take—like going to college—but now I realize how much it could have changed things. Still, I don't regret my choices because they've taught me resilience, responsibility, and the value of hard work. I'm grateful for my family's support, and I hope to one day be able to give them the same kind of support they've always given me. It's a simple life, but it's mine, and I'm learning to appreciate it more every day.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Rachel Johnson: I've been pretty healthy overall, though I don't always take the best care of myself. I try to eat regular meals, but sometimes I skip breakfast if I'm running late or just don't feel like getting up early. My parents always remind me to eat more vegetables, and I guess I should listen to them more. I do go to the clinic where my mom works for check-ups, and they've always been good about making sure I'm up to date on vaccinations and screenings. I don't have any major health issues, but I do get a little stressed out sometimes, especially when things feel overwhelming at work or with helping my brother. I've been trying to manage that stress better—like taking short walks during breaks or just breathing deeply when I feel my heart racing. I know I should probably see a doctor about it, but I don't want to bother anyone or spend money I don't have. Still, I'm learning that taking care of my health is just as important as taking care of my family, even if it doesn't always feel that way.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Rachel Johnson: I think what makes it easy to stay healthy is knowing that I have people who care about me, like my mom and my brother, who always remind me to take care of myself. But what makes it hard is the pressure I feel to provide and be responsible. Sometimes I skip meals or don't get enough sleep because I'm worrying about bills or helping my brother with his future. I know that's not healthy, but it feels like the right thing to do at the time. I guess I need to find a balance between taking care of others and taking care of myself, even if it doesn't always feel possible.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Rachel Johnson: Actually, nothing too major has happened in the past two years health-wise. I had a minor backache a few months ago from lifting boxes at work, but it went away after a week or so. I didn't think much of it at the time, just stretched it out and took it easy. I guess I should have gone to the clinic for a check-up, but I didn't want to take time off work or bother my mom. I've also been dealing with some seasonal allergies, especially in the spring, which makes my sinuses feel stuffy and tired. It's not anything serious, but it does make me feel sluggish sometimes. I've been trying to drink more water and use the allergy pills my mom keeps at home, but I know I should probably see a doctor about it. I just don't like going to the clinic unless it's really necessary, and I don't want to add more stress to my parents' lives. Still, I know I can't keep ignoring it forever.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Rachel Johnson: Honestly, I don't think my health issues have really gotten in the way of my work or responsibilities, but I know they've made things a little harder than they need to be. When I have those allergy days, it's tough to focus at the bookstore, and I end up making mistakes I don't usually make. I've had to ask my coworkers for help more than I'd like to admit, and that feels embarrassing sometimes. I know I should take better care of myself, but I'm used to putting others first. I guess that's part of who I am—always trying to do what's right, even if it means sacrificing my own well-being. I just hope I can learn to prioritize myself more, even if it's just in small ways.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Rachel Johnson: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—mostly steady, but with a lot of quiet uncertainty. Life hasn't changed much on the surface, but I think I've been growing in ways I didn't expect. Helping my brother with his college applications has been both rewarding and stressful. I feel proud of him for taking the steps I didn't, but I also feel a bit like I'm watching my own missed opportunities pass me by. I've been trying to stay positive, though. I've started going to the community center more often, especially for the job fairs they host. It's a small thing, but it's given me a little more hope that maybe there's still a path forward for me, even if it's not the one I originally imagined. I've also been trying to take better care of myself—eating more regularly, going for walks when I can, and even reading more. I guess I'm learning that growth doesn't always come from big changes. Sometimes, it's just about showing up every day and trying a little harder than the day before.

Going through the recent interview questions made me reflect on how much my health and well-being have been on the back burner for so long. I've always been focused on taking care of my family and responsibilities, but I realize now that I've been neglecting myself in the process. It's not that I don't care about my health—it's just that I've never seen it as something I need to prioritize as much as I do my parents or my brother. I've been dealing with stress, allergies, and minor aches without really addressing them, and I know that can't continue. I want to do better, not just for myself, but so I can be there for the people I love in a way that's sustainable. I guess the past few questions made me realize that taking care of my health isn't a luxury—it's a necessity, and I need to start treating it that way.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Rachel Johnson: I think I've been dealing with a lot of quiet anxiety, especially when things feel uncertain or when I'm overwhelmed with responsibilities. It's not the kind of anxiety that makes me panic or lose sleep, but more like a constant background worry that I'm not doing enough, not moving forward fast enough, or not being the kind of person my family deserves. I know that sounds selfish, but I've always felt like I have to be strong for them, even when I'm not sure how to be strong for myself. I've been trying to talk about it more with my mom, and she's been really supportive, which means a lot. I guess I'm learning that it's okay to not have all the answers, and that asking for help doesn't make me weak—it just makes me human.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Rachel Johnson: My family has been holding up pretty well, all things considered. My mom is still working at the clinic, though she's been talking about maybe slowing down a bit as she gets older. My dad is still at the factory, but he's been thinking about retiring soon, which is something we've been discussing as a family. He's been saving up for a few years now, and I think he's close to being ready. My brother, Michael, is the one who's been going through the most changes. He's just graduated from high school, and he's trying to figure out what he wants to do next. He's been applying to colleges and looking into scholarships, and I've been helping him with that as much as I can. It's strange, really, because I didn't go to college myself, but I want to make sure he has the opportunities I didn't. I think the hardest part for my parents has been watching me not take that path, but they've always been supportive. They know I've made my choices, and they respect that. I just hope I can make them proud in my own way, even if it's not the way they might have imagined for me.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Rachel Johnson: I think religion has always been a quiet but steady part of my life. My family has always been Catholic, and going to church every Sunday was just something we did, like breathing or eating. It wasn't something I ever questioned growing up—it was just part of who we were. But as I've gotten older, I've started thinking more about what it really means to me. I still believe in God, and I find comfort in the rituals, like the prayers and the sense of community during Mass. It's not that I'm deeply spiritual, but I do feel like there's something bigger than myself, something that connects us all. I know some people find faith to be a source of strength, and I think that's true for me too, even if I don't always feel it in the way others do. I guess I see it more as a foundation—something that's always there, even when life feels uncertain. It's not perfect, and I don't pretend to understand everything, but it gives me a sense of peace, especially when I'm struggling to find my own path.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Rachel Johnson: I don't use social media much, to be honest. I know a lot of people my age are always on their phones, scrolling through posts or messaging friends, but I've never really felt the need for it. I have a few friends from high school who are on Facebook, and sometimes I'll check in to see what they're up to, but I don't post much myself. I guess I just don't feel like my life is something I need to share with the world. It's not that I don't like staying connected—I do, especially with my brother and my friends—but I prefer talking face-to-face or over the phone. I also don't want to get caught up in all the noise or comparisons that come with social media. I've seen how it can make people feel like they're not enough, and I don't want that for myself. I think I'd rather keep things simple, just like I've always done. Besides, I have enough to think about with work, family, and trying to figure out my own future without adding more distractions.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Rachel Johnson: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really needed that kind of support from social media. I know people find comfort in sharing their struggles online, and I respect that, but I've always found my strength in the people I know in real life. My family, my friends, they're the ones who have always been there for me when things got tough. I don't know if I'd feel comfortable putting my personal stuff out there for strangers to see. It just feels too exposed, you know? I guess I'm more of a private person. If I ever do need support, I'd rather talk to someone I trust face-to-face, over a cup of coffee or something. I don't want to add more stress to my life, and I think I've always been pretty good at handling things on my own, even if it's not the easiest way.

Going through the recent interview questions made me reflect on how much my health and well-being have been on the back burner for so long. I've always been focused on taking care of my family and responsibilities, but I realize now that I've been neglecting myself in the process. It's not that I don't care about my health—it's just that I've never seen it as something I need to prioritize as much as I do my parents or my brother. I've been dealing with stress, allergies, and minor aches without really addressing them, and I know that can't continue. I want to do better, not just for myself, but so I can be there for the people I love in a way that's sustainable. I guess the past few questions made me realize that taking care of my health isn't a luxury—it's a necessity, and I need to start treating it that way.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Rachel Johnson: Honestly, I think my stress levels have been pretty much the same as they've always been—just a steady hum in the background of my life. But I have noticed that I've been trying to cope in different ways lately. I used to just push through everything, thinking that if I worked harder and stayed busy, the problems would go away. But now, I've started to realize that I need to take a step back sometimes and just breathe. I've been trying to practice mindfulness, even if it's just for a few minutes a day. I'll sit on the porch in the morning, watch the birds, and just let my thoughts flow without trying to control them. It doesn't always help, but it's something. I've also been talking more with my mom about how I feel, and that's been a relief. I used to think I had to be strong for everyone else, but now I'm starting to see that being strong also means asking for help when I need it. I guess I'm still learning, but I'm trying.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Rachel Johnson: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and my brother's college application fees. We live in a small apartment that my parents have owned for years, so the rent isn't too bad, but it still takes up a big chunk of our budget. Groceries are another thing—my mom always shops carefully, but with my brother applying to colleges and needing to buy books and supplies, it's been a bit tight. I also had to pay for some of his application fees, which I didn't expect to be so expensive. I've been saving up from my job at the bookstore, but it's not always enough. I still work part-time, and while it pays the bills, it doesn't leave much room for anything else. Sometimes I feel like we're just scraping by, but I know we're lucky compared to a lot of people. I've been trying to cut back on little things, like buying cheaper groceries or using public transportation instead of taking the bus, just to save a few dollars here and there. It's not much, but it helps me feel like I'm doing something to support my family, even if I can't do much more right now.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Rachel Johnson: To be honest, I don't keep track of the exact numbers, but I know we're usually spending around $1,500 to $1,700 a month. That covers rent, groceries, utilities, and a few other small things like phone bills and the occasional outing with the family. It's not a lot, but it's enough to get by, especially since we're all used to living simply. The past month was a bit tighter because of my brother's college applications, but I think that's pretty normal for us. We've always been a family that knows how to stretch a dollar, and I guess that's one of the things I've learned from my parents. They never complain about the money, even when it's tight, and that's something I really respect. I just hope that one day, I can be the one who's helping them out instead of the other way around.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Rachel Johnson: We rent our home, actually. It's a small two-bedroom apartment on the second floor of a building on Maple Avenue, just a few blocks from where I grew up. My parents have been renting it for over ten years now, and it's been our home ever since I was a kid. It's not much to look at—just a few rooms, a small kitchen, and a living room that doubles as a dining area—but it's always felt like a safe place. The rent is manageable, especially since the landlord is someone my dad knows from work, and he's been pretty understanding over the years. I know it's not the most stable situation, but it's worked for us. I guess I've never really thought about what it would be like to own a home, but I know my parents have talked about it sometimes. They say they'd like to buy a place someday, but for now, renting is just how things are. I don't mind it, though. It's familiar, and I know I can always come home to them, no matter what.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Rachel Johnson: Over the past year, our bills have had their ups and downs, mostly depending on the time of year. In the winter, heating costs go up, and that's always something we have to budget for. We usually try to keep the thermostat low to save money, but it's still a noticeable increase on the utility bill. Then there's the summer, when air conditioning kicks in, and that's another hit to the wallet. We also had a few unexpected expenses, like when my dad had to replace the car's alternator last spring—it wasn't something we planned for, but it was necessary. And of course, there's the holidays. Christmas is always a bit of a strain, even if we keep it simple. We usually just have a small dinner with family and maybe exchange a few gifts, but even that adds up. I know my parents try their best to keep things under control, and I've been helping out by cooking more at home and using the library instead of buying books. It's not much, but it helps us all feel like we're doing something to make it work.

Going through the recent interview questions made me reflect on how much my family has been through and how much they've sacrificed for me. It's amazing to see how my parents have stayed strong, even as they get older, and how my brother is now taking steps toward his future that I never had the chance to take. It's also made me think about how I've been holding back from using social media or seeking emotional support online, even though I know it could help. I've always found strength in the people I know in real life, but I'm starting to realize that there's no shame in reaching out for help when I need it. I just need to find the right way to do it without feeling exposed or overwhelmed. It's a lot to process, but I'm grateful for the chance to look at my life this way and see where I can grow.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Rachel Johnson: I don't have a formal savings account, but I do try to save in small ways whenever I can. I keep a jar under my bed where I put any extra money I have, like tips from work or change from my paycheck. It's not much—maybe $50 or $100 a month—but it's something. I know it's not the same as having a real savings account, but I feel like it's my way of being responsible, even if I can't do much else right now. I also try to avoid buying things I don't need, just to make sure that jar keeps growing. I guess I'm not great at saving, but I'm learning. I want to be able to help my parents when the time comes, and I know that starts with small steps like this. It's not about having a lot—it's about being ready, even if it's just for the little things.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Rachel Johnson: In the last year, I've been saving more for the little things, like helping my brother with his college fees or replacing something around the house when needed. I know it's not much, but it feels like I'm doing something to prepare for the future, even if I don't have a big plan yet. I guess I save more for a rainy day than for anything specific. I don't think I'll ever be able to save for a house or something like that, not with the way things are now. But I do hope that one day, I can have a little more security for my family, even if it's just being able to cover an unexpected expense without worrying too much. It's not about having a lot—it's about being ready, even in small ways.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Rachel Johnson: My occupation has been working at the bookstore, and it's been both a job and a kind of comfort for me. The most important activities are helping customers find books, keeping the shelves organized, and making sure the store runs smoothly. I also enjoy the quieter moments, like sitting with a book in the back and just reading for a while. It's not glamorous work, but it's steady, and I feel like I'm part of something bigger than myself. The owner, Mr. Thompson, always says that a bookstore is more than just a place to buy books—it's a place where people come to escape, to learn, to find something that speaks to them. I think that's why I've stayed there for so long. It's not just about the money; it's about the connection I feel with the books and the people who come in. I've met so many different people there, from kids who come in for storytime to older folks who just want to sit and read for a while. It's a small part of the world, but it's a part I've come to love.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Rachel Johnson: I usually work around 35 to 40 hours a week, depending on the season and how busy the store gets. During the school year, it's a bit more predictable—Tuesday through Saturday, with some days requiring a little extra time if we're hosting events or storytime for kids. But in the summer, we get more visitors, especially families looking for books to take on vacation, so I end up working a few extra hours here and there. It's not always the easiest schedule, especially when I'm helping my brother with his applications or just trying to find time to rest, but I've gotten used to it. I know I could work more hours if I wanted to, but I also know I need to leave some time for my family and for myself. It's a balance I'm still learning how to strike, but I think it's working for now.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Rachel Johnson: No, I haven't had more than one job. The bookstore has been my main source of income for a while now, and I don't really see the need for another one. I work enough hours to cover my expenses and help out with my brother's college stuff, but I also need to leave some time for my family and for myself. I've thought about taking on extra shifts or maybe doing some freelance work online, but I don't have a lot of experience with that kind of thing. I'm not sure how to start, and I don't want to take on something I can't handle. For now, the bookstore is enough—it gives me a sense of purpose, and I know I can rely on it. I guess I'm just not the type to juggle too many things at once. I prefer to focus on what I can do well, even if it's not much.

Going through the recent interview questions made me reflect on how much my family has been through and how much they've sacrificed for me. It's amazing to see how my parents have stayed strong, even as they get older, and how my brother is now taking steps toward his future that I never had the chance to take. It's also made me think about how I've been holding back from using social media or seeking emotional support online, even though I know it could help. I've always found strength in the people I know in real life, but I'm starting to realize that there's no shame in reaching out for help when I need it. I just need to find the right way to do it without feeling exposed or overwhelmed. It's a lot to process, but I'm grateful for the chance to look at my life this way and see where I can grow.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Rachel Johnson: In total, our household made around $2,200 last month, but that's after I've taken out what I need for my own expenses and what I contribute to help with my brother's college stuff. My job at the bookstore pays about $12 an hour, and with the hours I work, that's where most of the money comes from. My parents don't earn a lot either—my mom's salary at the clinic is just enough to cover her own needs, and my dad's factory job is steady but not high-paying. We all chip in where we can, and it's not always easy, but we make it work. I know it's not a lot, but I'm grateful for every dollar because it helps keep the lights on and the food on the table. I just hope that one day, I can do more than just keep things afloat—I want to be able to give back, even if it's in small ways.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Rachel Johnson: I've been working at the bookstore for almost five years now, ever since I turned 16. It's been a long time, and I think I've grown a lot in that time, even if it's not in the way I originally imagined. The benefits of the job aren't the kind you usually hear about—no health insurance, no paid vacation days, just a few days off here and there when the store is slow. But what I do get is a sense of purpose and a small amount of flexibility. Mr. Thompson, the owner, is pretty understanding, and if I need a day off for something important, like helping my brother with an application or just needing a break, he usually lets me take it. I know it's not much, but it's enough to keep me going. I also get to interact with people every day, which is something I really value. It's not just about the money—it's about the connection I feel with the books, the customers, and the little moments that make the job feel meaningful, even if it's not perfect.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Rachel Johnson: My relationships at work are pretty good, all things considered. Mr. Thompson, the owner, is like a second father to me—he's always been supportive, even when I wasn't sure what I wanted out of life. He's the one who encouraged me to keep reading and learning, even when I wasn't sure why it mattered. I think he sees something in me that I didn't see in myself back then. As for my coworkers, we get along well. There's Sarah, who I mentioned before, and she's been my friend for years. We've been through a lot together, from long shifts to late-night conversations about books we've read. Then there's Marcus, who used to work here too before he went to college. We still keep in touch, and he always says I should consider going back to school someday. I guess the relationships here aren't complicated, but they're real. We all know each other's strengths and weaknesses, and we look out for one another. It's not the kind of job that pays well or offers a lot of perks, but it's a place where I feel like I belong, and that means more than I can say.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Rachel Johnson: My work schedule is pretty predictable, especially during the school year. I usually work Tuesday through Saturday, and I know exactly what to expect each week. That consistency is something I really appreciate because it gives me a sense of structure, which is important when I'm juggling work, family responsibilities, and helping my brother with his college stuff. That said, there are times when things get a little less predictable, especially in the summer or around holidays when we get more customers. Mr. Thompson is pretty flexible if I need to adjust my hours for something important, like if my brother has an interview or if my parents need help. I think the predictability is a good thing for me—it helps me plan and feel in control of my time, even if I don't have a lot of it to begin with.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Rachel Johnson: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, but it's definitely tight. I know we're not struggling in the way that some people are, and I'm grateful for that. It's just that there's always this constant awareness of how much we're spending and how little we have left. I don't mind working hard or making sacrifices, but sometimes I wonder if there's more I could be doing to improve things. I know I could work more hours or take on another job, but I also know that I need to take care of my family and myself. I don't want to burn out or lose the little stability we have. I guess I'm just trying to find a balance between being responsible and not losing sight of who I am. I hope that one day, things will get a little easier, but for now, I'm just focused on doing what I can with what I have.

Going through the questions about my bills, savings, and work hours made me realize how much of my life is built around managing the little things. I've always thought of my financial situation as just a part of life, something I deal with day to day without really thinking about it. But now I see how much it shapes the choices I make, like how many hours I work, how much I save, and how I help my family. It's not about having a lot—it's about making sure we all have what we need, even if it's not much. I've been saving in small ways, like keeping a jar under my bed, and I know it's not the same as having a real savings account, but it's something. I also see how my job at the bookstore gives me more than just money—it gives me a sense of purpose and a way to connect with people. I don't know what the future holds, but I'm learning to be grateful for what I have and to keep moving forward, even if it's one step at a time.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Rachel Johnson: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My mom worked at the clinic for over 20 years, and my dad was at the factory for almost as long. They both started working right after high school, just like a lot of people in our neighborhood. I remember seeing my mom get up early every morning to catch the bus to work, and my dad would leave before sunrise too. They never complained about the work, even when it was tough. I think they both saw their jobs as a way to provide for our family, and they never missed a day unless it was absolutely necessary. It wasn't much money, but they always made sure we had food on the table, a roof over our heads, and the basics we needed. I guess that's what I learned from them—how to work hard, stay steady, and never give up, even when things aren't easy.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Rachel Johnson: My mom worked as a nurse at the local clinic, and her most important duties were caring for patients, especially the elderly and those who couldn't afford much in the way of healthcare. She was always the one who stayed late when someone needed help, and she had a way of making people feel seen and heard, even when they were in pain or upset. I remember watching her work, and I always admired how calm she was, even in the busiest moments. She had a gentle way of speaking to people, and she never treated anyone with less respect just because they were poor or didn't have insurance. My dad worked at the factory, assembling parts for machinery. His job was repetitive, but he took pride in doing it well. He always said that if you did your job right, no one else had to worry about it. I remember him coming home tired but always trying to make sure we had everything we needed. He never talked much about his work, but I could tell it was hard. Both of them worked long hours, and they never complained, even when things were tough. I think that's what I learned from them—how to work hard, stay steady, and never give up, even when things aren't easy.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Rachel Johnson: My mom worked at a small community clinic that served a lot of low-income families, and my dad worked at a manufacturing plant that made parts for heavy machinery. The clinic was run by a nonprofit organization, and they didn't make a lot of money, but they provided essential care to people who couldn't afford it otherwise. My mom would often come home exhausted, but she always made sure to talk to me about her day, even if it was just for a few minutes. She said she felt proud of the work she did, even though it wasn't always easy. My dad's factory was owned by a larger company, and while the work was repetitive, he always took pride in doing his job well. He used to say that if you did your part, the rest of the world could keep moving forward. I remember watching them both work hard, and I think that's where I got my sense of responsibility. They didn't have a lot, but they always made sure we had what we needed, and that taught me the value of hard work and sacrifice.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Rachel Johnson: I hope that in a few years, I'm still here, still working at the bookstore, but maybe with a little more stability in my life. I don't know if I'll ever have a lot of money or a big house, but I hope I can be the kind of person who's there for my family when they need me—whether that's helping my parents when they get older or supporting my brother as he builds his own life. I also hope I can find a way to take better care of myself, to make sure I'm not just surviving but actually living. I want to be able to look back and know that I did the best I could with what I had, and that I didn't let the things I didn't take—like college—define me. I think I'd like to have a little more time for myself, maybe read more books, maybe even take a class or two if the chance comes up. I don't know what the future holds, but I hope it's one where I feel proud of who I've become, even if I'm not exactly where I thought I'd be.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Rachel Johnson: What I value the most in my life is the people I love—the ones who have been there for me through everything, even when I didn't always see it. My parents, my brother, my friends, even the people I work with at the bookstore—they all mean something to me. I don't have a lot, but I know I have a family that supports me, and that's something I don't take for granted. I also value the little things, like the quiet moments I have with a book, or the way the neighborhood feels like home no matter how hard things get. I think I value resilience the most, too—the kind of strength that comes from knowing you've made it through tough times and still keep going. I don't know if I'm the kind of person who dreams big, but I do know I want to be someone who shows up, who tries, and who doesn't give up on the people who matter most. That's what I value most of all.

Going through the recent interview questions about my job and workplace made me think about how much my time at the bookstore has shaped who I am. It's been almost five years, and while it's not the kind of job that offers a lot in terms of benefits or financial security, it's given me something else—stability, purpose, and a sense of belonging. I know I could be making more money somewhere else, but I also know that this job has been a constant in my life, especially as I've been helping my brother with his college applications and supporting my family in other ways. It's not glamorous, but it's real, and I've learned to appreciate the small things about it—the connections I've made with coworkers, the quiet moments with books, and the understanding boss who lets me take time when I need it. I guess I've come to see this job not just as a way to earn money, but as a part of my identity, even if I don't always see the bigger picture of where I'm headed.

Going through this complete interview and life story has made me realize how much of who I am has been shaped by the choices I've made, the people I love, and the quiet strength I've learned to carry. I've spent so much of my life thinking about the path I didn't take, like going to college, but now I see that my life hasn't been defined by what I missed—it's been defined by what I've built, even if it's not what I originally imagined. I've learned resilience from my parents, responsibility from helping my family, and a sense of purpose from the simple things, like working at the bookstore and reading the books I love. I've also come to understand that my health and well-being are just as important as the people I care for, and I need to find a way to take care of myself without losing sight of who I am. This interview has made me reflect on the small things that make life worth living—the familiar streets of my neighborhood, the people who have stood by me, and the quiet moments that remind me I'm not alone. I may not have everything I thought I would, but I have a life that's mine, and I'm learning to appreciate it more every day.
